newsitem.title: SLOVENIA: Slovenia's right bids for power after close race.
newsitem.headline: Slovenia's right bids for power after close race.

text.p: Marjan Podobnik, leader of Slovenia's main right-wing party who is heading an alliance to form a new coalition, held out a conditional olive branch on Tuesday to centre-left Prime Minister Janez Drnovsek.

The People's Party chief said that, if his alliance failed to secure a parliamentary majority as a result of last Sunday's general election, it would be prepared to negotiate with Drnovsek's Liberal Democrats. The final official count in the prosperous former Yugoslav republic was expected on Friday.

"The result is very tight and (the alliance) has agreed it could possibly cooperate with the Liberal Democrats with the aim of establishing as stable a government as possible," Podobnik, 36, a prime ministerial hopeful, told a news conference.
But he made clear Drnovsek would have to give up his post as prime minister and his party relinquish the top positions of state it currently holds.
However, Liberal Democrat general secretary Gregor Gulobic told Reuters: "Under no condition will we participate in a coalition in which Drnovsek is not prime minister."

Unofficial results of Sunday's vote showed the so-called "Slovenian Spring" alliance, consisting of the People's Party, centre-right Social Democrats and Christian Democrats, winning 45 seats in the 90-seat parliament.
Drnovsek's Liberal Democrats won most votes with 27.04 percent and 25 parliamentary seats.
There was a slim chance that calculations of the complex voting system might produce an extra seat for the right-wing alliance, giving them a parliamentary majority.
Slovenia has made strides to establish a thriving economy. International credit agencies now rate the country on a par with the Czech Republic and ahead of Poland.
It has applied to join the European Union and stands a good chance of being included in NATO's first expansion eastwards.
Economic analysts have expressed concern over the prospect of a right-wing alliance taking power, saying privatisation could be stalled and foreign investment could slow to a trickle.
Political commentators said Drnovsek might still outmanoeuvre the alliance and persuade one of the rightist parties to join his Liberal Democrats in a new government.
Podobnik, whose party is backed by farmers hostile to EU membership, tried to allay fears that his party would push for slower integration into European institutions.
"Fear that our government would slow Slovenia's international integration is unfounded," he said. "We have a clear stand...in favour of (membership) of the EU and NATO".
Social Democrat leader Janez Jansa said EU membership was still on course, but a new government would have to ensure Slovenian interests were protected.
